bioghist.p: The Vaux family were prominent Philadelphia Quakers. The papers center on the family and business concerns of the surgeon George Vaux V (1721-1803) and his lineal descendants, George Vaux VII, and George Vaux VIII (1832-1915). Other, related families represented in the collection include the Warders, Sansoms, Heads, Graffs, Morrises, Cressons, and Mayberrys. George Vaux VIII was the Secretary and Treasurer of the Swatara Coal Company. He was interested in Quaker history and records and served as an unofficial correspondent for the Philadelphia Yearly Meeting with London Yearly Meeting. His brother, William Sansom Vaux (1811-1882) was a mineralogist and member of the Academy of Natural Sciences.

scopecontent.p: The 18th century material includes the trans-Atlantic correspondence of James, Richard, and George V, along with domestic correspondence relating to family and business affairs. Several letters discuss Philadelphia during the British occupation, and seven discuss yellow fever in 1797-1798, with a particularly fine letter by Ann Warder discussing the epidemic of 1798. The participation of George Vaux VII in a Quaker mission to the Seneca Indians in 1803 is well documented. Later correspondence, almost all personal and familial in nature, documents the interest of George Vaux VIII in mineralogy, his travels abroad, and Vaux genealogy. The collection also includes correspondence of William Sansom Vaux, much of it related to mineralogy. The collection also contains business correspondence and records of William Sansom, James Vaux, and several George Vauxes and includes receipts, vouchers, correspondence, share certificates, tax documents, legal documents (printed transcripts, verdicts/decisions, statements, and filings), receipt books, daybooks, and ledgers. (1792-1825). Records in the collection documenting the Deborah E. Emlen, William Sansom, Robert Morris, John and Sally Norris Dickinson, Michah M. Moore, John Gordon, Mary M. Johnson, and Cassady family estates include deeds, land records, inventories, correspondence, and vouchers (1700s-1870s). Swatara Coal Company records include correspondence and letter books, dividend book, and account books (1794-1870s). There are also pamphlets and reprints related to mineralogy; almanacs, some with annotations; maps and land surveys; newspapers, broadsides, and other ephemera.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found in the following collections: Haverford College: Vaux family papers and Vaux collection of correspondence, documents, and graphics; Friends Historical Library, Swarthmore College: George Vaux family papers.
